rdf:Alt.rdf:li: {\rtf1 (soft instrumental music)}
{\rtf1 - So in this lab we're\par going to be going through}
{\rtf1 the lifecycle of a log,\par from its generation}
{\rtf1 all the way through to storage\par and search capabilities.}
{\rtf1 For this class I have to use something}
{\rtf1 to be able to show you SIEM\par and tactical analytics.}
{\rtf1 For that we are using Elastic Stack.}
{\rtf1 Now don't get hung up on\par this, this is absolutely}
{\rtf1 not an Elastic Stack class,\par but I have to have something}
{\rtf1 in order to show you\par capabilities and processes}
{\rtf1 in order to analyze logs\par to find the bad guys}
{\rtf1 we need to go through certain things.}
{\rtf1 In this lab we are willing to go through}
{\rtf1 all the different pieces a SIEM utilizes,}
{\rtf1 whether it's a commercial\par SIEM from a top five}
{\rtf1 magic quadrant or even in\par this case the Elastic Stack.}
{\rtf1 So what we're going to be\par showing is logs coming in}
{\rtf1 to a log aggregator, in\par this case it's Logstash.}
{\rtf1 From there we'll go into\par an optional buffer piece.}
{\rtf1 In this lab we'll be using RabbitMQ.}
{\rtf1 From there that'll provide resiliency,}
{\rtf1 the ability to do software updates}
{\rtf1 and to handle back pressure\par or performance issues.}
{\rtf1 Then logs will be pulled out of the queue}
{\rtf1 and ultimately stored\par into back end storage,}
{\rtf1 or in this case, Elasticsearch.}
{\rtf1 Once the logs are in\par storage they just sit there}
{\rtf1 and do nothing until we\par manually analyze them}
{\rtf1 or use automated tools\par such as alert engines.}
{\rtf1 In this class we'll be manually\par searching logs with Kibana,}
{\rtf1 we'll be generating\par alerts with ElastAlert,}
{\rtf1 this is a tool developed by Yelp.}
{\rtf1 We also could use scripts\par or any other thing}
{\rtf1 'cause again, once it's\par in storage you query it,}
{\rtf1 you design and launch it.}
{\rtf1 So in the first book of this\par course we are focusing on}
{\rtf1 SIEM architecture,\par because you need to know}
{\rtf1 how to handle data, how to bring it in}
{\rtf1 and what your capabilities you have.}
{\rtf1 So this will be lab one, one.}
{\rtf1 The first thing we need to\par do before you start this lab}
{\rtf1 is run Docker start RabbitMQ.}
{\rtf1 What this command is\par doing is simply running}
{\rtf1 the RabbitMQ message broker service}
{\rtf1 that you'll need later in the lab.}
{\rtf1 This is normally disabled\par because we only use it}
{\rtf1 in this lab and there's\par no reason to have it}
{\rtf1 running otherwise, and let's face it,}
{\rtf1 some laptops aren't as strong as others}
{\rtf1 and they might struggle with having}
{\rtf1 everything running at once.}
{\rtf1 So run Docker, start RabbitMQ\par before beginning this lab.}
{\rtf1 Now in the first step\par what we're simply doing}
{\rtf1 is verifying that we can send\par logs to a central location.}
{\rtf1 We're basically simulating a log agent}
{\rtf1 sending logs to a log aggregator,}
{\rtf1 and for this we're Filebeat and Logstash.}
{\rtf1 The first thing we're going\par to do is start up Logstash.}
{\rtf1 We're going to open up a black terminal}
{\rtf1 and in there we're going to run Logstash}
{\rtf1 with the Debug.conf configuration file.}
{\rtf1 So this terminal is emulating\par what would normally be}
{\rtf1 a remote host listening\par and waiting for logs.}
{\rtf1 The difference is instead\par of sending the logs}
{\rtf1 to back end storage, it's\par going to print 'em the screen}
{\rtf1 just so we can verify things are working}
{\rtf1 the way they should be.}
{\rtf1 So when you run the\par Logstash with the Debug.conf}
{\rtf1 configuration file it's going to start up}
{\rtf1 and what we need to do\par is wait to make sure}
{\rtf1 our log sesh is fully loaded.}
{\rtf1 This means we're waiting\par for it to say at the end}
{\rtf1 of the output, pipelines running.}
{\rtf1 Once you see that it means\par log sesh is fully loaded.}
{\rtf1 When you see that then we\par can open a second terminal,}
{\rtf1 this will be a purple terminal\par or what we'll refer to}
{\rtf1 as the agent terminal, purple\par terminal, anything like that.}
{\rtf1 This is because we're\par simulating a remote agent}
{\rtf1 sending to a central log aggregator.}
{\rtf1 In the purple terminal we're\par going to run the configuration}
{\rtf1 fall for lab one, one which just tells it}
{\rtf1 to send the logs from\par Filebeat over to Logstash.}
{\rtf1 Once you hit enter you\par should start to see logs}
{\rtf1 come into Logstash.}
{\rtf1 Now once you receive a\par few logs and you verify}
{\rtf1 this is working you've completed the step}
{\rtf1 and you can hit Control\par C in the black terminal,}
{\rtf1 that will tell Logstash to stop.}
{\rtf1 When you first press\par Control C it's not going to}
{\rtf1 immediately just stop, what\par you're going to need to do}
{\rtf1 is wait until you see\par pipelines terminated.}
{\rtf1 Once you see that Logstash\par is no longer running,}
{\rtf1 you can switch to the purple terminal}
{\rtf1 and also hit Control C to\par stop Filebeat from running.}
{\rtf1 So next what we're going\par to do is take logs,}
{\rtf1 bring them into Logstash, but this time}
{\rtf1 instead of printing to the screen}
{\rtf1 we're going to send them into\par a back end storage system}
{\rtf1 or basically Elasticsearch.}
{\rtf1 So we're going to first start Logstash}
{\rtf1 with the aggregator\par only configuration file.}
{\rtf1 This will be in the black terminal.}
{\rtf1 Next, we're going to run Filebeat\par again in the purple terminal,}
{\rtf1 so we have logs going from\par Filebeat into Logstash.}
{\rtf1 This time however the black\par terminal is not going to show}
{\rtf1 any logs because it's not\par outputting to the screen,}
{\rtf1 it's outputting to Elasticsearch.}
{\rtf1 To verify this is working\par we need to open up Firefox}
{\rtf1 and then we're going to click\par on the bookmark for Cerebro.}
{\rtf1 Now Cerebro is just a web\par application for managing}
{\rtf1 and looking at Elasticsearch indices}
{\rtf1 and if you're not familiar with this}
{\rtf1 just think of this as kind of\par like a traditional database.}
{\rtf1 When you first load\par Cerebro you're going to see}
{\rtf1 indicies that just elastalert status,}
{\rtf1 elastalert error and other indices.}
{\rtf1 There's a lot of precaptured\par data I've already preingested}
{\rtf1 for each of the labs, you\par could look at those later}
{\rtf1 and they're already in Kibana,\par but what we're looking for}
{\rtf1 is to see if logs were stored in an index}
{\rtf1 called lab one, one, aggregator only.}
{\rtf1 To find this in the\par filter indices search bar,}
{\rtf1 you can simply type 1.1 and you should see}
{\rtf1 the lab one, one aggregator only.}
{\rtf1 You will also see some dash completes,}
{\rtf1 those are just where I ran\par through the labs ahead of time}
{\rtf1 and captured the data for\par you to compare against}
{\rtf1 if you see so, choose.}
{\rtf1 Now if you have the indices\par switch back to Filebeat}
{\rtf1 and Logstash and hit\par Control C to close them.}
{\rtf1 You've confirmed that you\par have data in Elasticsearch.}
{\rtf1 Now that data is in Elasticsearch\par I want to actually see it}
{\rtf1 so I can do analysis.}
{\rtf1 For that we're going to use Kibana.}
{\rtf1 So switch back to Firefox,\par click on the Kibana bookmark,}
{\rtf1 and in here we need to tell\par Kibana how to submit a search}
{\rtf1 against the indices of lab\par one, one, aggregator only.}
{\rtf1 So for this we're going\par to click on management,}
{\rtf1 we're going to click on index patterns,}
{\rtf1 and then we need to click\par on create index pattern.}
{\rtf1 Now in this step all's\par we're actually doing}
{\rtf1 is creating a dropdown\par of indices to submit}
{\rtf1 a search against, this\par can support wild cards}
{\rtf1 so that it searches\par across multiple indices}
{\rtf1 or in our case we want\par it to directly search}
{\rtf1 just the new indices we\par created of lab one, one,}
{\rtf1 aggregator only.}
{\rtf1 So type in lab one, one, aggregator only,}
{\rtf1 then click on next, in the\par timestamp selection field}
{\rtf1 we're going to click the\par dropdown and select at timestamp}
{\rtf1 and then again, create the index pattern.}
{\rtf1 From here you now can\par select the index pattern}
{\rtf1 to search the logs that were brought in.}
{\rtf1 To do this click on the discover tab}
{\rtf1 and then you should see logs\par that just got brought in}
{\rtf1 from your virtual machine.}
{\rtf1 If you didn't it's possible\par that you've ingested}
{\rtf1 or ran Logstash longer than 15 minutes ago}
{\rtf1 which is the default time and to fix that}
{\rtf1 you just click on time\par in the top right corner}
{\rtf1 and select something like last five years,}
{\rtf1 and you should be able to\par see logs at this point.}
{\rtf1 In the prior steps we\par used Filebeat to send logs}
{\rtf1 to Logstash and then from\par Logstash we stored them}
{\rtf1 directly in Elasticsearch.}
{\rtf1 The problem with this is\par there's a redundancy issues}
{\rtf1 and issues with larger amounts\par of peak events per second.}
{\rtf1 Too much data to Logstash, too\par much queries to Elasticsearch}
{\rtf1 and other conditions can cause outages}
{\rtf1 or performance hiccups.}
{\rtf1 What we can do is introduce\par a broken or a message cue}
{\rtf1 or also referred to as a buffer}
{\rtf1 to handle these kind of situations.}
{\rtf1 So what we're going to do next\par is we're going to take logs}
{\rtf1 from Filebeat, send them into Logstash,}
{\rtf1 and then from Logstash we're\par going to neatly dump them}
{\rtf1 into a broken, or in this case RabbitMQ.}
{\rtf1 To do this run Logstash\par using the aggregator}
{\rtf1 to broker a configuration file.}
{\rtf1 Now this time instead of\par outputting to Elasticsearch}
{\rtf1 Logstash is going to output to RabbitMQ.}
{\rtf1 So once you see pipelines\par running switch to the purple}
{\rtf1 terminal and run Filebeat\par again so that we get logs}
{\rtf1 going into Logstash.}
{\rtf1 Now this time if you were to go to Cerebro}
{\rtf1 you would not see any logs,\par any additional indices}
{\rtf1 or any of that because we're\par not logging to Elasticsearch.}
{\rtf1 Instead, switch to Firefox\par and there's a bookmark}
{\rtf1 for RabbitMQ, this will let us see}
{\rtf1 what's in the buffer or broker.}
{\rtf1 Log in with student and\par a password of sec555}
{\rtf1 and on the homepage of\par RabbitMQ you're going to see}
{\rtf1 a line that says ready.}
{\rtf1 Ready is basically saying\par I have X number of logs}
{\rtf1 in the broker that are\par awaiting to be pulled out}
{\rtf1 and then used.}
{\rtf1 So we also click on the\par cue tab and the production}
{\rtf1 environment, you might have\par a cue for Windows logs,}
{\rtf1 a cue for intrusion detection system logs,}
{\rtf1 a cue for firewall logs, and this is great}
{\rtf1 because not only are you\par getting the buffer or broker}
{\rtf1 capability but you also can tell what logs}
{\rtf1 are maybe getting backlogged.}
{\rtf1 Now once you confirm you\par can see the logs in RabbitMQ}
{\rtf1 go ahead and switch to\par Logstash in the black terminal,}
{\rtf1 hit Control C to stop it, and\par switch to the purple terminal}
{\rtf1 to stop Filebeat.}
{\rtf1 Now in order for the\par broker to work properly}
{\rtf1 we need to have another\par instance of the aggregator}
{\rtf1 pulling logs out of it.}
{\rtf1 Now in the first instance it\par would just be shoving data}
{\rtf1 directly into the broker and not making}
{\rtf1 any modifications to the logs, no parsing,}
{\rtf1 no log enrichment, no anything.}
{\rtf1 The second copy is going to\par pull logs out of the broker}
{\rtf1 and it's going to do the heavy lifting,}
{\rtf1 the parsing, the\par enrichment, and all of that.}
{\rtf1 So what we're going to do\par now is run Logstash again}
{\rtf1 this time with the broker to\par storage configuration file}
{\rtf1 which in production would've\par been a separate aggregator.}
{\rtf1 When we run the configuration\par file and we see pipelines}
{\rtf1 running immediately switch\par into RabbitMQ's interface again}
{\rtf1 and you should see the cue or the ready}
{\rtf1 within a few seconds go to\par zero which basically means}
{\rtf1 the logs have been\par pulled out of the broker}
{\rtf1 and now are in Elasticsearch as similar}
{\rtf1 to the previous step.}
{\rtf1 So again, this is simulating\par doing aggregator to buffer}
{\rtf1 or broker and then aggregator\par pulling them back out of that.}
{\rtf1 Once you've confirmed the logs\par are pulled out of RabbitMQ}
{\rtf1 switch to the black terminal}
{\rtf1 and stop Logstash with Control C.}
{\rtf1 To prove the logs that\par came from the broker}
{\rtf1 actually came from that I\par have the configuration file}
{\rtf1 for the broker of the storage,\par place them into an index}
{\rtf1 called lab one, one, broker.}
{\rtf1 To view the logs in this\par click on the bookmark}
{\rtf1 in Firefox for Kibana and\par again, we need to allow Kibana}
{\rtf1 to know how to submit a\par search against that index}
{\rtf1 or what index pattern to use.}
{\rtf1 So for this within Kibana\par click on management,}
{\rtf1 from there click on index\par patterns and click on}
{\rtf1 create index patterns again.}
{\rtf1 This time the index is\par lab one, one, broker.}
{\rtf1 The timestamp field is still\par going to be at timestamp,}
{\rtf1 go ahead and create that index pattern}
{\rtf1 and then switch to the discover tab.}
{\rtf1 From the discover tab you'll\par build or click the dropdown}
{\rtf1 and select the lab one, one\par broker and search those logs.}
{\rtf1 So searching logs with Kibana is great,}
{\rtf1 in manual analysis you're\par going to find a lot of things}
{\rtf1 that are hard to do in\par an automated fashion,}
{\rtf1 but we still need a way to search logs}
{\rtf1 in an automated fashion.}
{\rtf1 For example, 50 field\par log ons or root forcing,}
{\rtf1 I should have an alert\par generate that says hey,}
{\rtf1 I found this within the\par logs that you've captured}
{\rtf1 and for that you need an alert engine,}
{\rtf1 specifically in this class we're\par going to be using ElastAlert.}
{\rtf1 For this step we're going\par to use a command called}
{\rtf1 elastalert test rule and\par we're going to point it}
{\rtf1 at a rule called lab one, one frequency.}
{\rtf1 This rule is simply just\par finding logs you've ingested}
{\rtf1 in the prior steps that can\par contain the Linux sudo command.}
{\rtf1 So if it sees this it will generate alert.}
{\rtf1 Now when you run this\par command it's going to crawl}
{\rtf1 Elasticsearch and look\par for those conditions}
{\rtf1 and it will find them and\par output some of the logs}
{\rtf1 to the screen and then\par also say that it suppressed}
{\rtf1 the rule because it's\par already been triggered}
{\rtf1 which is what it would be\par configured to do in production.}
{\rtf1 So alerting alert engines\par are simply just crawling}
{\rtf1 your store systems\par looking for or performing}
{\rtf1 some type of complex query.}
{\rtf1 Now at the end of this\par lab you need to run Docker}
{\rtf1 stop RabbitMQ because you\par won't need it for future labs.}
{\rtf1 We just use it to emulate\par the buffer process of a SIEM.}
{\rtf1 Now in this lab we've\par taken logs and shipped them}
{\rtf1 across the network with\par an agent, Filebeat,}
{\rtf1 into an aggregator,\par Logstash, into an optional}
{\rtf1 buffer piece, RabbitMQ,\par from that we pulled the logs}
{\rtf1 back out using another\par aggregator, Logstash,}
{\rtf1 which then stored them into\par a back end storage system,}
{\rtf1 Elasticsearch.}
{\rtf1 Now once the data was\par there we then searched it}
{\rtf1 with Aguvi, Kibana and then we implented}
{\rtf1 an automated search with\par alerting with an alert engine,}
{\rtf1 ElastAlert.}
{\rtf1 So a SIEM is a multi-component\par system that gets}
{\rtf1 fairly complex really quickly.}
{\rtf1 You need to understand how\par all these different pieces}
{\rtf1 interface so that you can take them,}
{\rtf1 think outside the box,\par and implement tactical}
{\rtf1 SIEM implementations.}
{\rtf1 Again, just like logs\par are in the storage system}
{\rtf1 and we use Kibana or ElastAlert}
{\rtf1 if you want to do anything outside the box}
{\rtf1 why not run a partial\par script or a Python script,}
{\rtf1 you can make it happen\par but you have to understand}
{\rtf1 how everything is working.}
{\rtf1 So that completes lab one, one.}
